Remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2011130 and this version literally can go all the way up until 10mm screw/bolts. Also I included a clip that acts as a bolt to hold the drawer together in place by using the cap.

Do download and customize them according to your requirement.

There are also files for the drill guide, along with the script to adjust according to your generated spool drawers

Read the full guide on: https://learn.adafruit.com/diy-lego-led-bricks/3d-printing

In this week’s project, we’ll show you how to add LEDs to your Legos.

These Light Bricks are 3D printed and have tiny LEDs inside.

They’re pretty cool for adding lighting effects to your scenes and you can easily connect to them to regular lego’s.

You can make them in several colors and turn them on with a tiny button on the side.

Compared to official light bricks, these diffuse the whole brick instead of just being a spotlight.

They’re both the same size but offer different lighting. The lego light bricks are great for pointing light, while the 3D printed brick glows brighter and can fit in tighter spaces.

But you can connect them together to make interesting combinations that illuminate your projects.

You can 3D print the bricks using opaque filament on almost any desktop 3D printer.

remixed_from.author: raab6
remixed_from.title: OpenRC F1 Front Spoiler flexible mount and stronger spoiler

description.text:
This is a remix of the 2017 wings that Daniel uploaded over on Pinshape. I took his files and made some customization. They match the general design of the 2017 cars. Wider wings and more aggressive sweep.

Rear wing: Added some strength at the mounting point
Front Wing: Added some strength where mine break, also modified to mount using the design raab6 uploaded.

I haven't printed these yet! I'm confident they will work fine- but I haven't had the time/material ready to make them

Update 2/26/17: I printed the front wing and realized I one of the features was backward... updated model has not been uploaded.
Update: 2/26/17 (2): New models uploaded for front wing.
Update 3/12/17: New front wing design

comments.text: Thanks for this remix. Files work well.

These are WIDE tires for the openrc F1 car. I took Daniel's tires that he added to pinshape.com and added studs.

These tires will fit on the original rims and axle- but will work better with the new wider parts. I honestly haven't even printed the 2017 axle or rims yet.

Please note I have only tested an earlier version of these. They had GREAT grip but wore out quickly. The version uploaded here has 3x more studs of a larger diameter. I'm hoping they will wear slower like this. Give me a week or 2 and I'll have them tested!

I print the tires with just two walls and 0% infill. 1mm top and bottom thickness.

title: Geeetech Aluminum Prusa I3 Floating Z Axis

description.text:
It's near impossible to center the z axis threaded rod in the couplers provided with the kit. Instead of screwing the threaded adapter directly to the z axis carrier, mount it to this to let the z-axis carrier "float" on the threaded rod and drastically reducing the wiggling introduced by a crooked or off-center threaded rod.

This version requires an additional 8mm of vertical space below the carrier and above the coupler which can cause issues if the coupler isn't sunk down as far as possible or if centering couplers are used.I have plans for another revision that recesses the thread adapter into this piece further.

title: Modified x belt mount for Prusa to increase build height

description.text: Since I use a direct drive extruder, the x carriage belt was hitting the frame before anything else limiting the z below 100 mm. To avoid this, I installed the idler bearing inside the x idler end and designed a new belt clamp. This allowed me to go as high as 120 mm.

The position of the hole for the bearing in the x idler end is off-center so that if you use a bearing guide, it will hit the frame. I used a spare threaded rod as a file to enlarge the hole.
To apply tension to the belt, use a bulldog clamp to hold one end of the belt, while you apply tension with one hand on the other end and push the lock in with your other hand. Then screw the clamp on the x carriage.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

No

It started as a double Helix on the botton stetched to account for deposition type of printers and added primities; torus, cylnder and hoiur glass and then on top used a sphere with bridging to create the holes and curved structures. All the elments were then welded together with Mesh Fusion tools (Modo).

This is my first edition of a recorder-like flute instrument which features a bored, coiling sound chamber to achieve a lower register in a small form factor. It's sized like an ocarina, but sounds more like a recorder (the acoustic reasons for which are pretty complicated, but suffice it to say that it has a long chamber which coils around rather than an large hollow chamber like an ocarina). Its closest relative would seem to be the Renaissance Rackett instrument (the sausage bassoon), which is a double reed wind instrument featuring coiled tubing bored into wood. I tried to make one of these with wood using a dremel tool a few years ago but didn't get very far. 3D printing makes experimenting with the design far easier.

This is just my first attempt at making something like this--I'll make better versions soon. Please stand by for improvements (like a dual-chamber duet flute) as I intend to make this an ongoing project! I didn't bother with figuring out a tuning for it, and in a 5x2" version I printed it sounds rather like an Indonesian scale. And the fingering is killer on your fingers--I intended to play it by laying my entire fingers across the rows of holes kind of like how people play the mijwiz instrument. But it doesn't work that great.

If you print and it doesn't work, try using an x-acto knife to shave away imperfections. The slightest protrusion in the wind chamber or on the labium (yes, that's what it's called) can throw the sound off or make it entirely soundless.

Please feel free to take the design concept and run with it--I'd really like to see innovation in the field of compact coiled wind instruments. The concept is laughably under-explored. It would work with double-reed (like the oboe or shawm), single-reed (like the clarinet or mijwiz), and free reed (like the hulusi--although in my experiments so far I've been unable to get PLA to work as a free reed. Maybe ABS would work?) sound sources as well. And it doesn't have to be a recorder fipple at the end--it could be a notched groove like the shakuhachi or an open hole like the fife if that's what you're more comfortable with.

comments.text: "I'd really like to see innovation in the field of compact coiled wind instruments. The concept is laughably under-explored."
comments.author: magic612

comments.text: Thanks for stopping by! There's one other compact coiled flute design I saw on the Thingiverse, so someone beat me to it.
comments.author: magic612

comments.text:
The idea of folding some long music instrument into compact one is attractive. But as I know woodwind instruments tend to develop into ergonomic designs instead of compact designs. Consider the design of oboe Bb with 23 holes that has so much mechanics, or soprano saxophone Bb with 26 holes, that has a bit less mechanics over holes. All of their mechanics intended for ergonomic playback with no more than 9 fingers.
Can you convert this flute into something like
0 000
00000
00000
00000
000
``0
comments.author: alex_belov

comments.text: Hi, I've been working on a dual-chamber design which would have a more natural fingering, but haven't had much time to really test it.  In any case, this would not be a quality instrument, just something fun to pull out of your pocket or backpack.  The fingering as is is surprisingly comfortable if you lay the pointer and middle fingers of each hand across the flute on either side.  Each of your four fingers should be covering two holes in this case, and you go up the scale by first lifting the lower part of your left fingers, then raising the tips of your left fingers, then the tips of your right, and finally the lower part of your right fingers.  Hopefully that makes sense.  This doesn't allow for virtuoso playing, but gets the job done.

print_settings.Notes:: I used supports for the base

description.text:
This guide provides a solid ring, yet the filament can be easily removed if needed. I didn't like how almost every other guide has a gap for the filament to find its way back out of, or worse, get jammed in and mess up a print -- nor was I content with a strip of blue painter's tape as a solution. Also, there might be times I want to remove the filament from the guide, but not from the extruder, and this makes it super easy.

UPDATE: 3-1-17
I modified the Base piece by filleting the front left edge of the bottom section. While I hadn't experienced any problems, I thought it would decrease the possibility of filament getting snagged. The mod is evident on the 3D model, but the photos are of the previous iteration.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I used supports for the base

Assembly

The mating areas on the guide's bottom piece and the base will need to be cleaned up a little before gluing. I made the tolerances tight, planning to have to remove a little material to ensure a tight fit. I used dollar store superglue (cyanoacrylate).

Installation

The Base piece can be installed from the front left side of the LCD screen, and slides to the right. I made tolerances very tight, so sanding the channels in the base may be necessary to slide it over the acrylic. I planned to do that anyway to get an appropriately tight fit until I get more in tune with my printer and can confidently design in fit tolerances. Better to have some extra than not enough.

title: Heat Bed Corner Glass Adapter - Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1257772

But made it from scratch in OpenScad.

In my case I've got 5 pieces of glass cut by local glass store, they are a bit imperfect, so in some cases it is required to use an adapter to fit it firm.

Also this model includes an M3 Washer and M3 Nut hole.

Attaching STL model which should fit a popular size glass sold on amazon (200 x 213 mm). By printing the model, you will have only two corners covered. For other two corners you have to mirror it in the slicer programm or use OpenScad model to adjust the sides.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

90%

Notes:

Use a filament matterial with the highest melting point available. For example, if you make it from PLA plastic, and will use with the heating bed for printing ABS, the corner will melt with the bed temperature over 85 celsius

Settings

y_lenght, x_lenght :: The length of the corner sides not including outer border.
outer_border :: how far this model will stand out of the bed
glass_thickness :: my glass is 3mm thick but I've used 2.8 value to give a little bit more room over here, as bottom layer of the top surface is not perfectly straight, but curly and wavy
bed_thickness :: my bed has a Wanhao M3 pad on it. So it is bit thicker as default heating bed. Also I've added 0.2 mm to keep the global model size the same, after glass_thickness parameter.
y_thick, x_thick :: THIS IS THE MOST IMPORTANT. How far the side will overlap your bed, depends on your glass size.
under_layer :: Thickness of the bottom of the corner model, the part which is under the bed.
bolt_area :: small hole in the top surface to be able to insert a bolt

Adjusting an Openscad

I've used my small library 3d.scad to make my life easier, so you should also download it in order to have main model working. Place it into LIB folder one level up or just simply adjust the path in the beginning.

Washer and nut holes

This model is not ment for snuggling by M3 bolt, washer, nut. It let the nut to go through. But only prevent it from moving to the left or right.

A snuggling is achived by selecting a proper distance between bottom and top surfaces. bed_thickness setting should be used in the open scad model.

comments.text: Any Idea if this will work on the wanhao v2.1?
comments.author: 3D_Creations_Lab

comments.text: If your heat bed is the same as shown on this picture https://wanhaousa.com/products/duplicator-i3-steel-frame than it should work fine. But you should make sure that you have a m3 nut and non conductive washer under the heat surface like described over here http://3dprinterwiki.info/wiki/wanhao-duplicator-i3/duplicator-i3-basic-mods/bed-screw-and-thumbwheel-mod/
comments.author: 3D_Creations_Lab

comments.author: villain13

comments.text: I don't know about v2.1, but for the i3 plus version it was an issue by not having this nut and washer, as the spring under some circumstances may damage the heating bed and result in current short. To prevent this, it was a solution to add a washer and tie it with the nut, so the spring will be touching the washer.

comments.author: sharkattack99

comments.text: There is so much overhang with all the scopes. I can't imagine ever getting any clean edges. The scopes needs to be broken down into more pieces. Also, the resolution is low meaning allot of these curves will need allot of post print work to make it look smooth.
comments.author: macktruck

comments.text: The scopes are FAR too complicated and intricate to cut up and properly fix for printing (trust me, i tried). the bigger scopes were a bit simpler to cut since they're, y'know, bigger. however if you have a slicer that does good support material (like Cura, for example) then there shouldn't be TOO much roughness on the underside, and even if there is, it won't be very noticeable since it'll be mostly pressed up against the gun. as for the resolution, well there's nothing i could really do about that. The models either get lowered in resolution automatically, or have to be because they crash my slicer and 3Dmodeling programs (good example is the Brute spiker i made. took 4 times as long because it kept crashing maya whenever i tried to cut it). either way you are right, i have a nice set of files and lots of sandpaper for just that reason.

description.text:
Español

Módulo de OpenSCAD que permite trabajar con patrones hexagonales tipo panal los cuales pueden ser luego aplicados a otras superficies mediante intersección.

  • honeycomb: Se muestra en la figura 1 y genera el patrón libremente.
  • honeycombCube: Se muestra en la figura 2 y es la aplicación del patrón a un cubo para generar mediante intersección un cubo hueco con el patrón.

English

OpenSCAD module that allows working with honeycomb hexagonal patterns which can then be applied to other surfaces by intersection.

  • honeycomb: is shown in figure 1 and generates the pattern freely.
  • honeycombCube: is shown in Figure 2 and is the application of the pattern to a cube to generate by intersection a hollow cube with the pattern.

URL

https://gitlab.com/joaquinfq/openscad/blob/master/Modules/Pattern/honeycomb.scad

description.text:
I wanted to make a practical gift to bring to my brother in Florida. They entertain a lot so I thought some tropical coasters would be fun. I got the idea from these two things: Citrus Slice and Citrus Coaster but there were elements I wanted to change. First off as a coaster you want a spot where the water can collect, second I wanted a design where you could stop the print, switch filaments and continue. I started with white on the multi-colored ones. These are printed in Filaflex TPU, it's very similar to Ninjaflex. Neither will scratch your table. For an alternate design see my Flower Coasters design.

I create these designs to encourage people to try out flexible filaments or get some new interesting colors of flexibles. For info on purchasing samples of several brands of flexible filament see flexyfilament.com

title: Dual dock charging station for Apple Watch and iPhone

description.text:
This is a multi-function dual dock charging station for an iPhone and an Apple Watch.

It has been tested with an iphone and an iphone plus, with and without protection case. Even it have been tested with a book-like cover on an iphone 7 and it fits.

To place the watch charger, pass the USB end through the front hole from the outside to inside the case. Then press gently the charger until it sits on the hole.

You can coil both USB cable on the inside to keep it organized while charging or during travels.

If you insert the cover on the groove located at the central column, it acts as a support for the iphone when it is charging.

If you lay the case on a lateral side, it can act as a watch stand, as you can see on the pictures.

I printed it on PLA without any support. Infill at 5% is enough.

Hope you enjoy it!!!

Comments are welcomed.

To make this you will need 4"-4.5" of 5/16" threaded rod, three nuts, one washer (recommended), and two standard 608ZZ shielded 8x22x7 miniature ball bearings. (these are the same ones that all fidget spinners use!)

Other Maker Select / i3 style printer mods I've made:

title: Standing Cube - can your printer handle this ?

description.text:
Printed in spiral vase mode with 3 bottom layers - maybe you need to add a skirt for better printbed adhesion. (Don´t print it filled - will waste a lot of material and we all know this will be printed fine). Spiral Vase is the key ;-)

This is a very challenging print in my opinion - I can get it to complete but the walls aren´t flat. ABS is not working at all due to layer adhesion issues.

Try this out with your printer and post the result here (via "I´ve printed it").

Would love to see your prints and how they turn out.

description.text:
I modeled this after a Blind Valance Clip 32E for my blinds. The plastic clips keep breaking and the replacements are ridiculously expensive, so a little time in Fusion 360 and this worked nicely. I beefed them up so they are a little harder to get on the blinds and get the valances onto the clips, which also makes them harder to break and accidentally knock off when cleaning. Hopefully this works for someone else.

This may or may not work for your blinds, but give it a print and try it out. Its a small part, so shouldn't take much filament.

** Update V2
The first version I uploaded failed, where the PLA broke from fatigue. I beefed up the section that broke and printed at 100% infill to try to make it stronger. The clip is even harder to get on the valence now, but seem strong. I may have to make some more modifications, but only time will tell. I am placing this thing as a work in progress until I know more.

description.text: This little penguin is made of a dodecahedron with a pyramid added to one face for a head; a cuboctahedron stretched along one axis for his body, and pentagonal prisms for feet. The polyhedra for this penguin were generated in (free for download) JavaGami software (http://l3d.cs.colorado.edu/~ctg/Projects.html).

I was able to get a successful print on a Replicator 2 of the entire penguin as a single job (penguin full.thing) -- be sure to use a raft and generate support, which will produce a column under the beak and between his feet.  One of the photos shows the finished piece sitting in the MakerBot.  For ease of printing, I have also included the separate parts.  
For folks printing from the .stl files -- the head is scaled to 20 mm in Z; the body is 30 mm in Z; and the foot is 25 mm in Y.  
The decorated penguin shown in the photo was printed in white ABS (on a Dimension SST), and then surface-primed with acetone and painted with acrylic.  His eyes are black paper circles made with a hole punch.

This is a standard layout for a SCS-10LUU Bearing block for a standard LM10LUU Linear Bearing. This is the Long 10mm Linear Bearing. It features an extruded end stop and lock ring notch for holding the bearing in the block.

comments.text: How is the bearing fixed inside? Have you already tested them with metal bearings? What is the infill needed?
comments.author: konstantinwall

comments.text: They are friction fit in the pillow block with a lock ring notch to ensure the bearing stays in place. The design when printed to spec with 50% infill requires the LM10LUU to be pressed into the block. This can be achieved by submersing the printed block in a hot water bath to soften the PLA/ABS and then inserting the bearing. You can also drive the bearing into the block by tapping on it with a hammer. If you use the latter method I recommend using a nut the size of the bearing attached to a bolt or threaded rod as a driver ram.

description.text:
Have you crashed your DJI Mavic Pro and cracked your gimbal plate? Print this replacement part and get back in the air!

I started designing this to be an exact copy of the original, and then tweaked a few areas to add some strength improvements. This part will not be nearly as rigid as the original, but should tolerate another crash without snapping (the entire assembly hangs from rubber bands, so rigidity is not a concern).

I printed in PETG, .175 height, 100% infill.

Front LED mount for Realacc X210.
Fits perfectly the Matek LED board (www.banggood.com/Matek-RGB-5050-LED-Lamp-Panel-16V-4S-Lipo-7-Colors-Switch-For-FPV-Helicopter-Multi-axis-p-985685.html)

I took this excellent design and turned it on its head because I needed an enclosure to hold all my 3D Printer parts in something more monolithic and still able to hold an ATX Power Supply. I am very happy with the results. The minor changes allow me to stack as many of these modules as I want. The system will hold a C3D Remix board as well as a custom ATX power breakout and breakout board that allows me to run a ribbon cable from the printer to this box rather than the mass of wires that we usually see. In these pictures you can see that I am test fitting a 7" touchscreen which I will mate either to a RasPi Octoprint rig or a stick PC. Ultimately, all the printer's controller components would be in this box. The power supply is a 450W, but you can put any standard ATX type supply in here.

comments.text:
This looks particularly awesome.
I'm curious about a few things tho...
It looks like you have the basic LCD most printers come with mounted up front -- is the SD card slot still accessible?
For someone crazy new to customizer (and OpenSCAD as it happens) do you have any suggestions on how to modify the PSU area for a 24V (which is what the printer I have this in mind for needs) PSU such as a Meanwell?
And finally, given that the printer this will be destined for is, in fact, a freaking rats nest of cables (fully assembled that way from the manufacturer too!) any links to the ribbon cables/connectors you're using?
Thanks!
comments.author: jdknetts

comments.text: Sadly, it is not.  The reason is that primarily, I have never really bothered with the SD card slot.  My intention was to install a computer right on top (a RasPi), for control, again on the same power supply that is in it, so that there is no reason really to have the SD card and the controller is really just that, a controller and alternate status display.  Plus, if I really wanted to, I have an SD card extender that I could use to run the SD card slot outside the case.
comments.author: jdknetts

comments.text: That is absolutely beautiful! I am working on something like this myself, i haven´t thought about doing the enclosure in white, looks gorgeous.

comments.text: Why thank you!!  I have a new board that is going on it (waiting for some connectors), that allows me to have just 2 cable sets between the printer and the controller: one is a ribbon cable for data (motor control, end stops, thermistors) and power (hot end, heatbed).  And because I use terminal blocks on my printer, I can eliminate the rat's nest of wiring that these things typically have.
comments.author: TheXXL

comments.text: That is exactly what i am planning to do, having one rack insert for my powersupply, then another for the printer board and one for my octoprint. The only problem that i have found was how to get all the pins from the mainboard to my printer, i thought about 37pin connectors,  but for the life of me could not find cable for it. So i now went with 2 dsub 25pin connectors and premade cables. For heatbed and hotend i have xt60 connectors and some thick cable.

Yes, it's true ! There are a lot of 3d design about "clapton master" but since i love design and print so ... i did the mine too !

It's really simple to print, place the object in the plate like the shot in gallery.

To complete u need:

  • 1 M4x20 exagonal
  • 1 M4x10 round
  • 4x M4 nuts
  • 2 oring about 9/10 x 1.78

This works ONLY with zivipf spools !
If u need an adapter for other spool ... leave a comment with spool size :)

It's simple to use, really. U need a drill to use at low rpm.
U need place the coil master in a slippery floor becuase during clapton creation it need to move itself.

A demo video: https://youtu.be/Lsy0auZEG9k

description.text:
Mumei fut la femme de l'année 2016, même si la série a ses défauts. Il fallait donc lui rendre hommage.
j'ai sué quelques gouttes pour représenter et surtout imprimer correctement la plus badasse des héroïnes steampunk. Encore une fois merci d'être indulgent et de ne pas comparer bêtement à une figurine moulée. Évidement une maquette achetée dans le commerce sera bien plus agréable à l'oeil et évidement un professionnel de la modélisation ou tout autre artiste 3D feront mieux que moi. Tous les fichiers Blender que j'ai créés sont fournis (pour le buste prenez bien le fichier buste, car je ne l'ai pas modifié dans le fichier mumei_complet. Il y aura des trous).
Sinon faite des expériences avec mes fichiers. J'avais tenté d'abord une armature (voir fichier armature) Mais les déformations des jambes n'étaient pas réussites). Si ça vous tente le ficher en T est fournie avec l'armature ou sans. Attention, il risque d'avoir pas mal de faces loupées sur ce fichier, je les ai corrigé bien plus tard.
Pour ma part j'ai imprimé par partie, mais si vous voulez essayer la statuette en une fois, ...
Gambatte !

Dagoma discovery 200

Yes

Yes

fin

no

My first project, making a collar for my EX-girlfriends dog. (the big letters are the reason why it's not finished yet...)

I'll add everything i've done so far later on including the electronics i am going to use and if someone needs it, a wiring diagram if needed.

I want to make 2 plugs out of flexible Filament to make this thing as waterproof as possible, who knows when the dog wants to swim ;)

The transparent hose is for hydraulic purposes if i remember correctly and is thick and tough so a dog has to bite at least twice to damage it i hope. i used 42 cm but you can cut the hose down to the needed length.

The reason why i wrote big dogs on the one hand is it would look ridiculous on a e.g. french bulldog but on the other hand with the elektronics, mainly the Li-ion battery, it weighs just a bit more than a feather ;)

print_settings.Notes:: You have to use supports for part C. I would advise to print the part A form ABS or some other temperature tolerant plastic. PLA will work fine, but it will eventually degrade with higher temperatures. Good alternative for ABS is PETG.

title: True Delta leveling system with thermal insulation

description.text:
As much I like the option to use software leveling I find manual adjustment to be more reliable and intuitive way to get your heated bed leveled.

I designed a compact, low profile and adjustable heated bed mount for Kossel Mini which also includes a thermal insulation that will help to improve bed heat up time and ability to reach higher temperatures which are needed for printing ABS.

This thing is currently designed for quite precise 170mm diameter aluminium printbed, but glass may be work as well although the tolerances are pretty small.

If anyone wants, I can share the *.SLDPRT files as well.

E1: This system probably benefits form nylon insert lock nuts if you are using weak springs but with the proper springs the tension of the turning the screw is OK.

E2: I noticed that not weak springs that I used work well for printing but they make removing the print difficult since the printbed is quite loose. I ordered proper springs from Aliexpress (https://goo.gl/CpnWXm) and hope these are going to make a difference. - The springs arrived, but they were a bit too long for my M3 screws so I had to cut off about 5mm. In retrospect I would recommend to look for 15mm springs. Performance of the springs is very good, now the build platform is very sturdy and easy to adjust.

E3: Maybe in near furture I'll make my modification of Kossel corner pieces with the integrated bed mounting holes. Then the whole thing will be more compact and minimal! - I have my modification of Kossel corners ready but I would like to improve it further to improve the building process.

E4: I made a slight modification and added slot to apply some tension to the print surface, because I experienced the situation when bed rotated inside its holder. Also I added some additional holes for fixing plate A and B. The new V2 part should definitely be printed with ABS, because PLA will soften over 50C and lose it's flex.

E5: Added bed holder v3.1(B) which includes a nut trap for easier use. This version eliminates the need of cluing the nuts to the holder. v3.1 is for the M3 self locking nuts and v3.1B is for regular M3 nuts. Although self locking ones are recommended since they're harder to turn which allows finer adjustments, also they will not come loose due to vibrations.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Resolution:

0.2mm will be ok

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You have to use supports for part C. I would advise to print the part A form ABS or some other temperature tolerant plastic. PLA will work fine, but it will eventually degrade with higher temperatures. Good alternative for ABS is PETG.

BOM
  • A three pairs of printed parts
  • Purple heated bed
  • Ikea Cork Trivet (http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/87077700/)
  • 6x 6mm M3 bolts + 9x M3 nuts
  • 6x M4 bolts for mounting to the printer frame
  • 3x 15mm springs
  • 3x 10mm M3 bolts

Start from the place where is the thermistor cable. There is a small hole for it in the holder where you can conveniently put it thorough. If necessary cut away some excess cork to make room for the cable.

Repeat! Prepare the holding brackets

Use pliers (and super-glue if necessary) to press M3 nuts to their place. V3.1 has proper nut traps so super glue is no longer necessary!

Mount brackets to the frame

Later on I found out that when you mount the brackets with nuts upside then due to the tensions of the springs nuts could come out of their slots. To avoid that I would recommend glue the nuts to the brackets (to be sure they don't fall off) and mount the brackets with nuts facing down.

Mounting the bed

Connect all the wires and place bed to its place. Insert M3 bolts and springs and connect the heated bed to the frame.

DONE!

print_settings.Notes:: If you want the text to come out better, I'd recommend slowing the print down and using 0.1mm for the details on the faceplate and button.

description.text:
I was bored one day and decided I needed an enclosure for my LCD to attach to my printer. Seeing as how I had just completed building my enclosure for my printer, I felt a good place to mount it was on the front. Swivels up out of the way when you need to access the doors.

You can find the enclosure this was built for here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2124813

Printer:

Reach 3D Printer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you want the text to come out better, I'd recommend slowing the print down and using 0.1mm for the details on the faceplate and button.

Hardware Needed:

1.5mm metal rod. (Found at any Crafts or Hardware Store) Got mine from Lowes in their Hobby Drawer.
4x M3x16 Screws

Assembly:

You will need 4 spacers along with hardware listed earlier.
And you will need 1 of everything else.

Before installing screen, test fit all parts first. Depending on the quality of your printer, you may need to do a bit of sanding/filing to get the parts to fit. I tend to design everything with tight tolerances. Once everything is fitting snug like it should, you will need to tap the 4 screw holes on the back of the face plate. You may be able to thread with the screws but you may damage or crack the housing. Besides doing work like this, it's always a good idea to have a good Metric Tap set am I right :)

What I did for the 2mm rod on the bracket, I cut the rod down to size to match the length of the bracket, cut it in half, and ground the ends down until inserting each half into the sides of the brackets set flush in the center with each other. Length of the 2mm rod is 97.2mm as I designed. This rod will sandwich between the face plate and back plate where they will hinge.the hooks will face the back and down when folded. See above picture.

Feed the 2 LCD ribbons into the large hole on the right one at a time. Plug them back into the LCD. If you don't want to confuse the connections, I recommend using a marker to mark a 1 and 2 on each ribbon and their respective connector.

The 4 spacers are fragile so be easy with them. Start by lining them up between the 2 screen boards, tabs facing top and bottom facing front. The LCD board is slightly narrower than the control board which allows for the tab clearance. Recess the screen into the back half and run the 4 M3 screws through until they reach the front screen board. Be easy with this step as to not break the tabs on the spacers. The tabs help hold the spacer in place for the screw to feed through. Make sure the button is in the face plate, Stop facing right side up if you managed to get it to print right :P

Now turn back plate over on top of the face plate and snap the 2 together, ensuring the bracket is between the 2 halves of the swivel point, and finish tightening all 4 screws. Your screen is now ready to be mounted to the plexiglass enclosure that you have built. or whatever you have decided to mount it to.

Designed in OnShape

Care to create your own bracket for this enclosure?

Each side of the bracket is cylinder with an outer diameter of 8mm and an inner diameter 0f 2mm. The cylinders are 20mm in length. 2mm Cap on the outsides to hold the rod in. the insides are 61.2mm apart. Use these parameters for the hinge and design your bracket around it, and it should fit the enclosure :)

description.text:
I recently acquired a mini, USB powered tesla coil off of Ebay for about $20.00. Was really excited to see that it actually worked pretty good when I received it. Wanted to make something cool to show off to my friends at work so decided to make it into a 5V USB powered CFL lamp with a USB charging outlet for my phone.
Created the base box for this in Fusion 360 and printed it out on my Duplicator I3. A little soldering and hot glue and I was in business. Also had a Gas Discharge Nixie Tube laying around and decided to top the coil with that for a little extra effect.
Works great and a really neat way to show off wireless power using a harmless voltage to power a normally 120V bulb.
I did prepare the base drawing for a 1.5mm thick bottom plate with screw holes but wanted to get the base built first and didn't really need it. So if you want a cover plate you can design one pretty easily.

description.text:
This is a wall mount for the Amazon Echo Dot version 2. The screw hole countersinks are slightly oversized to recess a No.8 woodscrew and provide clearance from the Echo Dot.

It was inspired by a design by IMakeThisLookGood http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2066228 but with thicker walls to survive life in a teenagers room.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed with standard settings for ABS and with an 8mm brim to aid adhesion. I printed it the 'correct' way up but there is no reason not to invert it if you want a greater contact area with the print bed.
I have found my printer prints smoother in the Y axis compared to the X axis, presumably due to the greater bearing spacing, so I printed the wall mount with the side arms aligned to the Y axis as the back is hidden by the Echo Dot when in use.
Deburred with a sharp knife blade dragged at 90 degrees to the print edges, followed by a light sanding with P240 grade sandpaper using a sanding block to remove any layer lines.

Designed using Tinkercad. I started out with a cylinder 10mm bigger all round than an Echo Dot and then made an Echo Dot sized hole in it together with an extra slightly smaller hole for the front opening. I then removed the top and bottom segments to give the basic shape. To finish I added some holes for the screws and rotated the piece 90 degrees ready to print out.

print_settings.Notes:: There are 18 different pieces, so close-fitting parts may require some playing with settings - If everything's oriented properly in your slicer, every part can be printed without support material. I used rafts for most parts, but that was primarily due to an uneven print bed. A raft is really only necessary for the tall narrow parts like the two 'spikes', which need to be printed upside down. I got almost all of the parts to snap fit, but the three "hex" parts which hold up the wire ring holder needed a bit of hot glue as filler.

description.text:
This is a multi-component print that can be assembled into a set of steampunk-style glasses frames which snap-fit over standard safety glasses.
I made my set to wear to the FIRST Robotics Competition 2017 game, which has a steampunk these.

For more information, and to see all of my assembly/finishing/weathering steps, check out the YouTube video! https://youtu.be/-kdsEkqRBYY

Note on wearing: These frames are designed to snap-fit over regular polycarbonate safety glasses. The pressure of somebody wearing them is enough to make sure they don't snap out, but if you want, they can also be attached with a wire "twist tied" across the nose bridge in the middle. There are tiny holes in two of the triangles in front you can use to hide the tips of this wire.

There are 18 different pieces, so close-fitting parts may require some playing with settings - If everything's oriented properly in your slicer, every part can be printed without support material. I used rafts for most parts, but that was primarily due to an uneven print bed. A raft is really only necessary for the tall narrow parts like the two 'spikes', which need to be printed upside down. I got almost all of the parts to snap fit, but the three "hex" parts which hold up the wire ring holder needed a bit of hot glue as filler.

description.text:
foreign game to me,
but due to missing bail, emergency bail printed overnight.
very simple design for speedy process. field tested now,
PLA with 40% upstanding print does not withstand direct hits.
Picture shows broken bail.
V2 has stl for horizontal print.

Printed upright, height is around 110 mm.
shorter end to the bottom to minimize support material. Used 40% infill for added strength, which is not sufficient for a direct hit, upright print introduces weakest surface where most strength is needed.
V2 has horizontal, off board print stl, let me know if you required it for the V1 version.

description.text: I needed an enclosure for my 3D printer and these 2 gentlemen had parts in their files that worked perfectly for this build so I do believe appropriate credit is due there. I designed additional files to complete my printer which is found here. Along with the files I used from elkayem's and schlem's projects.

Printer:

Reach 3D Printer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Most everything you can print with 0.2mm layer height. However some of the more detailed pieces like my knob and 2" Port might want to use 0.1mm layer height to get the detail.

Hardware Needed:

A wooden board for Base. It does not matter what size board, as long as it meets your width and length requirements for your enclosure. I used a 1/2" finished plywood.
Wood Screws #10x3/4 pack
2mm metal rod for door hinges. (Found at any crafts or hardware store)
Plastic Weld Epoxy.
Neodymium magnets 4x4mm x8 (For door latches and back plates)
M5x10 x8
M5x20 x2 For knobs
M5 washers 8-16 (1-2 per bolt per bracket to mount your Reach to the base.)
M5 T-Nuts
Rubber feet for the bottom of the board x6 (Optional, but on my build the screws came out the bottom a hair. The feet helped a lot. The pack came with 6)

Printed Pieces:

2x Top Back Corners
2x Top Front Corners
4x Top Sides
2x Bottom Back Corners
2x Bottom Front Corners
2x Sides
4x Door Hinges
2x Left Door°
2x Right Door°
1x 2" Port and Ring
1x Swivel plug for Bowden Tube
1x Vent
8x Plexi Mounts for securing your enclosure to the wood base
4x Printer brackets to secure the Reach3D to the base.
(If you use a different printer, you will need to design appropriate brackets for that printer. Or let it free stand.)
2x Knobs for doors (I designed the Triforce on these knobs. You can use whatever knob you like)
2x Back plates

  • Even though I called these Left and Right Door, they are in fact both used on each door. E.g. the Left door uses Left Door on top and Right door on bottom and same for Right door where Right Door is on top and Left Door is on bottom.
Assembly:

The beauty about this project is, the size is variable. You print the same pieces out and you cut your plexiglass pieces to the lengths you need them and it assembles to that size.

Once you have printed and gathered all your pieces you need, and cleaned out all support and all that good stuff. (I refer to the devilish Top Corners. As these were a bugger for me to clean out.) You will want to cut your base board and all your plexiglass pieces to size. Do not forget to cut the strips that go across the bottom and top fronts. Use a 2" hole saw for the 2" Port and also for the vent if you use it. Word of caution here. I did not design it so it has a lot of play in the hole so you will need to use extra glue. Or find a smaller hole saw that will fit it more appropriately. The 2" port will fit perfectly with the 2" hole saw. Use 1" hole saw for the swivel mount for the bowden pass thru. Drill hole for knobs. Make sure to take your time doing this and use masking tape on your cuts. Glue all pieces together. This is a time consuming process. I recommend gluing in stages and make sure all pieces fit perfectly. When you cut your 2mm rod down for your 4 hinges, Make sure you give enough to fully seat into the corners and still have the door hinges sit in the rods. I used a Dremel to cut my 4 rods and used a mallet to seat them into their corners. On the door latches it's important to glue the side with the hole towards the inside. Use a pair of channel locks or any press you like to press the magnets into each of the 4 holes Once you have everything glued with the enclosure upside down, this is a perfect time to glue the back plates. The magnets from the doors will help hold them in place. First press the magnets into the 4 holes on the back plates. These holes will also face away from the doors so make sure before you press the magnets in, that when you hold this back plate to the door, the magnets will attract and not repel each other. THIS IS IMPORTANT! Take your time here to make sure it's right. I made sure all magnets in the doors and back plates all faced the same direction for this. once you have your magnets in and ensure they attract each other, apply some glue to the top of the plates, the thicker portion away from the magnets, and attach it to the front strips. Making sure the magnets align with each other and apply pressure til it sets. Do this for the top and bottom.

When you are ready to secure the enclosure and your printer to the board with the wood screws, I recommend you mark your holes and drill pilot holes. This will prevent cracking.

Once everything is secured, don't forget to add your knobs. If you used mine, use a M5 Tap to tap the hole for the knob and feed the M5x20 through the hole in the plexi and secure it to the knob. Happy Printing.

Designed in OnShape

All pieces that I added to this project have been designed in OnShape.

title: Support pour plateau réglable sur ressorts - Discoeasy 200 / Dagoma

description.text:
Barettes pour que le Plateau de la Dagoma Discoeasy 200 soit réglable en hauteur.

Il faut imprimer le fichier STL en deux exemplaires. Les éléments à imprimer sont de dimensions réduites, ce qui a pour avantage d'être facile à imprimer si on a un problème de parallélisme (raison de l'upgrade envisagée ...).

Il convient de remplacer les 4 boulons à tête fraisée M3 x 10 par des boulons à tête fraisé M3 x 20mm (ceux montés sur la photo) ou pour plus de confort au montage par des M3 x 25mm.

Les 4 écrous freinés M3 d'origine sont réutilisés.

Les 4 ressorts mis en place sont des ressorts de compression acier, STANDERS, Diam.16.5 mm, L.27 x Ep.1.7 mm vendus par 4 en Grande surface de bricolage.

Ils ont l'avantage d'avoir un diamètre suffisamment large pour que les supports d'origine (couleur orange sur les photos) de forme légèrement conique leur servent d'épaulement, permettant de les centrer et de réduire la hauteur totale du dispositif.

title: Audio-technica ATH AD300 head support pads

description.text: This is a model of a replacement head pad for the audio-technica AD300 headphones. This is only the head pad, not any of the parts of the suspension mechanism. However, this head pad (single piece) replaces both of the original parts of the head pad while removing its ability to tilt backward and forward.

Printer:

Rebel II

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer height, 0.4 mm nozzle

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed with PLA. 2 perimeters. If you can, go for a 0.1mm layer height, you'll get much nicer edges of the holes.

I used a 15mm brim but if you go really slow, I guess you can succeed even without it. No support should be needed.

I also had to cool my bed down to 70C after the first layer to prevent model wobbling, but that is probably only my problem since I usually print at 90 or 100C bed temperature. I also suggest blowing at the model real hard or going slow because the layer time on this model is very short.

This model is the right pad. If you need the left one, flip the part in slicer.
Remove the brim (if any) and snap each had pad on the appropriate axis of the suspension mechanism.

The original pads on my AD300 got damaged so much that when you snapped them on they just fell off the headphones right away. This was because the super small plastic bits holding on to the axis on the suspension mechanism broke off. Because audio-technica does not offer replacement head pads, I decided to copy the original head pad simplifying it into a single piece in the process. This means I removed the ability to tilt forward and backward, only the left-right tilting remains.

print_settings.Notes:: The Hotend Housing requires some support on the external areas.  I did not place any support inside, the model has been designed to be able to print pretty close and bridge the top faces.  Print 4 or 5 top layers to give a nice clean look.

description.text:
UPDATE

I have found that the housing doesn't offer enough air flow to the bottom coils of the heatsink. This in turn causes a melt down in your hotend if your are running a Teflon tube inside your hotend. I will update this to remedy this problem.

I wanted a better effector for my Micromake D1. I found that there were a couple issues in regards to the z-probe, and the heat sink cooling that were just results of a bad design.

I also wanted to be able to pull the hot end out easily so I could service a jam or clog without having to take any screws or bolts out.

This is what led me to this design, it works completely off magnets and is easily clicked together or pulled apart, without anything being loose. The magnets are 5mm x 2.5mm and hold the parts together very well.

This design will also accommodate swappable hot ends, a simple connector for the electronics would be all you need to put in the line.

If you make one post a picture. Thanks, and enjoy.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50-60

Notes:

The Hotend Housing requires some support on the external areas. I did not place any support inside, the model has been designed to be able to print pretty close and bridge the top faces. Print 4 or 5 top layers to give a nice clean look.

comments.text: Nice design. It makes very easy to put accessories like a pen holder, dial indicator,etc instead of the hotend without using tools to screw/unscrew the holders. I will make one for my new printer.

I'm still new to 3D modeling and I thought this was cool so here is the STL file if you would like to edit or print this on your 3D printer. The process on how I made this 3D model is down below. Again, I'm still new to this so the model might not be very intricate like other 3D models out there. What I recommend doing if you are capable and want to make this model more personal is to extrude the bottom face and indent some text with whatever you like such as your name, your business, a quote, etc. Thanks for taking a look at this and I might post another model or an update to this later.

The Creation Process

I just created a basic dragon head shape in Adobe Illustrator, saved it as an SVG file, then imported it as a sketch in 123D Design, extruded the sketch, and finally punched out the eye and nostril holes. It is not too complex of a model, but I thought it looked cool.

Dragon Head Model Preview
This is a filament holder for anycubic prusa i3

description.text: This is a companion cube model remade for CNCing. While you COULD print this and glue it together, it's really meant for CNCing. There are 3 shapes total; Top, small side and large side. You need to mill 2 of each and then glue or fasten them together. Do not leave extra material on any dimension. Fusion 3d source file is included so you can go straight to CAM instead of trying to convert the STLs.

With constant effort to push the boundary of how small a brushless setup can get, the Swirlie was born.

Designed to be a small, simple setup, the Swirlie looks sweet and performs indoors and out.

It's 64mm sized (same as Inductrix), brushless, full removable prop guard, and tough.

-Flight Controller
Emax Femto (also compatible with other 20x20mm and 16x16mm hole spacing FCs)
-Motors
1102 or 1103 motors 8000kv-10,000kv. 10,000k recommended
-Props
40mm Props
QX70 (drilled out to 1.40mm)
Rakon Tri-blade (drilled out to 1.40mm)
RotorX or FuriousFPV cut to 40mm
-ESC
20x20mm hole spacing 4in1 6A-10A
-Receiver
Your favorite micro rx
-Camera/VTX
VM275T or your favorite micro AIO vtx
-Battery
300mah-450mah 2s-3s

title: Mobile Frame Zero: Shinonome SN-1H "Niku Hiki-ki"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
"The SN-1H, the most recent frame in Shinonome Frame Corporation's lineup, is designated the "Niku Hiki-ki" for its mass and high lethality. Although limited to solid ground in terms of mobility, the SN-1H more than compensates for it with a thick, multilayered carbon-based armour compound. Like its predecessor, its joints are powered by a combination of servos and hydraulic units, though optimized towards brute force rather than speed and responsiveness. When deployed, it often wields two belt-fed 4-barrel rotary guns that can be modified to shoot shells containing magnesium shot, armour-piercing flechettes, and other unconventional ammunition types. On the back of the SN-1H are two large pods that each house an array of supercapacitors. These supercapacitors require replacement approximately every 5000 hours due to the intense stress that they endure. Mounted onto the supercapacitor pods are dual missile pods and antennae that swivel to avoid obstructing the missiles. Despite the SN-1H being a large and prominent target on the battlefield, it neutralizes threats easily with a tungsten battle hammer, forearm-mounted mortars, and of course, its rotary guns. Some pilots take advantage of the SN-1H, executing opponents by throwing its hammer, and using its mortars at point blank when punching. If needed, its bulky supercapacitor pods can be swapped for a compact one-time-use battery located toward the rear of the hips (at the expense of its rockets and some armour)."

Got bored of my previous mech, so I rebuilt it into this. The torso actually hasn't undergone much modification. The LXF file contains the skeleton, the mech without backpack/weapons, and the fully armed mech.
